This weekly bulletin informs students, parents, and staff about internships, academic
programs, jobs, community service options, and leadership initiatives, along with
other student opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age
requirements, and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!
Please note that a good number of NEW programs are listed in today’s edition, please
check them out ASAP, as deadlines are rapidly approaching – several are highlighted
below:
EVENTS: Two STEM-focused fairs are coming up: The Bit By Bit Tech Conference
for female & non-binary students is tomorrow, (4/6) at Dalton High School in
Manhattan. And the Tri-State Engineering Expo (4/14) in White Plains, NY, is open
to all students with an interest in Engineering & Tech fields.
ACADEMICS: CUNY College Now free summer courses are available at campuses
throughout the city – the Baruch College registration deadline is today!
BUSINESS/JOBS: There is a new list of paid summer camp positions open to high
school students. The Museum of Finance Academy offers an excellent virtual
program of free finance/business-related classes to juniors & seniors – the application
deadline is April 9th. And the New York Public Library’s Business Plan
Competition is open to residents of Manhattan, Staten Island, and the Bronx. It offers
significant cash prizes – the first online orientation session is April 9th!
LEADERSHIP: Numerous excellent programs have deadlines coming uo in the next
ten days. These include the Student Historian internship at the New York Historical
Society (4/7), the Young Leaders Summit program for lower-income juniors (4/8),
the Sadie Nash Leadership Institute for female & gender-expansive youth (4/15),
among others.
MUSEUMS/ART: There is an Earth Day Poster Contest (Planet Versus. Plastics)
open to all- the deadline is April 8th. The Paley Center for Media in Manhattan offers
two summer programs (with one being a paid position) for current 10th and 11th
graders; the deadline for both is April 12th. The Guggenheim Museum’s Art
Detectives summer program for current sophomores & juniors offers arts conservation
& museum management training.
For students interested in architecture and urban design, the New York City College
of Technology (City Tech) in Brooklyn offers a one-month free program for current
10th and 11th graders. And Barnard College in Manhattan welcomes female 9th, 10th,
and 11th grade students to apply for their free three-week summer architecture
program.
STEM: The NYU/Tandon School of Engineering in Brooklyn offers a number of
summer Tech-focused programs for high school students, with some free and some
with fees – the next application deadline is April 14.
John Jay College in Manhattan offers a free two-day Forensic Science Lab
Workshop during spring break – the application deadline is April 15th. Stem Matters
is a free NYC summer STEM program for all grades, covering one-week or multi-
week sessions – apply by April 24th. And the Manhattan College (in the Bronx) free
Summer Engineering Program is open to 10th and 11th graders, with a focus on
under-represented and female students (but all may apply).
SCHOLARSHIPS: The Stuyvesant Alumni Association Scholarship Program is
accepting applications until April 26th – these are open only to Stuy students, so be
sure to apply!
